bestBHT.bht: The Pharisee takes pride in his voluntary fasting on Mondays and Thursdays, boasting about works of supererogation. He goes beyond the requirements of the law by giving tithes of all that he gains, not just his possessions. But God sees through his outward piety, recognizing the wickedness in his heart. This serves as a warning against relying solely on external acts of piety, emphasizing the importance of genuine humility and dependence on God's mercy for salvation.

Henry Alford: This was a voluntary fast, on the Mondays and Thursdays; the only prescribed fast in the year being the great day of atonement... So he is boasting of his works of supererogation."
The law perhaps (but compare Abraham’s practice, Gen. xiv. 20; and Jacob’s, Gen. xxviii. 22) only required tithe of the fruit of the field and the produce of the cattle"
His speech shows admirably what his trusting in himself was.
Albert Barnes: The religion of the Pharisee, therefore, consisted in: Abstaining from injustice to others; in pretending to live a harmless, innocent, and upright life; and, A regular observance of all the external duties of religion."

His 'fault' consisted in relying on this kind of righteousness; in not feeling and acknowledging that he was a sinner; in not seeking a religion that should dwell in the 'heart' and regulate the feelings; and in making public and ostentatious professions of his own goodness."
Most of all was this abominable in the sight of God, who 'looks into the heart,' and who sees wickedness there when the external actions may be blameless.
Marvin Vincent: The Pharisees fasted every Monday and Thursday during the weeks between the Passover and Pentecost, and again between the Feast of Tabernacles and that of the Dedication of the Temple.
The Israelite did not pay tithes of his possessions, but only of his gains - his annual increase.
The meaning possess being confined to the perfect and pluperfect.
John Calvin: the proud hypocrite, by winking at his sins, met the justice of God with a pretense of complete and perfect righteousness, his wicked and detestable hardihood could not but make him fall.

the only hope of the godly, so long as they labor under the weakness of the flesh, is, after acknowledging what is good in them, to betake themselves to the mercy of God alone, and to rest their salvation on prayer for forgiveness.
no man is pure from extortion, injustice, uncleanness, and other vices, unless he is governed by the Spirit of God.
Philip Schaff: His acts, he affirms, surpass the requirements of God’s law.
I give tithes of all that I get, not of what he possessed, but of what he gained.
It is easier to see the folly of the Pharisee’s prayer than to cease offering it ourselves.
Archibald T. Robertson: Twice in the week (δις του σαββατου). One fast a year was required by the law (Leviticus 16:29; Numbers 29:7). The Pharisees added others, twice a week between passover and pentecost, and between tabernacles and dedication of the temple.
I get (κτωμα). Present middle indicative, not perfect middle κεκτημα (I possess). He gave a tithe of his income, not of his property.
John Gill: Not 'on the sabbath', as the words may be literally rendered, and as they are in the Vulgate Latin and Ethiopic versions; for the sabbath was not a fasting, but a feasting day with the Jews.
It was forbidden a man to fast, until the sixth hour, on a sabbath day; that is, till noon.
This man would not be thought to be such an one.
John Wesley: I fast twice in the week — So did all the strict Pharisees: every Monday and Thursday.
I give tithes of all that I possess — Many of them gave one full tenth of their income in tithes, and another tenth in alms.
The sum of this plea is, I do no harm: I use all the means of grace: I do all the good I can.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Pharisee in this passage boasts about his voluntary fasting on Mondays and Thursdays, showing off his works of supererogation and trusting in his own righteousness. He follows the law by giving tithes of all that he gains, not just his possessions, and prides himself on exceeding the requirements of God's law. However, his outward piety and self-righteousness are detestable to God, who looks into the heart and sees the wickedness that lies beneath the surface. This passage serves as a warning against relying on external religious acts and highlights the importance of genuine humility and reliance on God's mercy for salvation.

The Pharisee in this verse brags about his voluntary fasting on Mondays and Thursdays, boasting of his works of supererogation. He proudly gives tithes of all that he gains, displaying his trust in himself and his righteousness. However, his outward displays of piety and self-assurance are abhorrent to God, who sees the wickedness in his heart. This verse serves as a cautionary reminder against relying solely on external religious acts, emphasizing the need for true humility and dependence on God's mercy for salvation.

The Pharisee proudly boasts of his voluntary fasting on Mondays and Thursdays, presenting it as a work of supererogation. He goes beyond the requirements of the law by giving tithes of all that he gains, not just his possessions. However, his self-righteousness and outward piety are detestable to God, who sees into the heart. This passage serves as a caution against relying solely on external acts of religion, highlighting the need for genuine humility and reliance on God's mercy for salvation.

The Pharisee takes pride in his voluntary fasting on Mondays and Thursdays, boasting about works of supererogation. He goes beyond the requirements of the law by giving tithes of all that he gains, not just his possessions. But God sees through his outward piety, recognizing the wickedness in his heart. This serves as a warning against relying solely on external acts of piety, emphasizing the importance of genuine humility and dependence on God's mercy for salvation.

The Pharisee proudly boasts of his voluntary fasting on Mondays and Thursdays, displaying works of supererogation. He meticulously gives tithes of all that he gains as a sign of his righteousness. However, his self-reliance and ostentatious religious acts are unacceptable to God, who discerns the wickedness lurking within his heart. This account cautions against placing undue trust in external religious practices, underscoring the vital need for genuine humility and dependence on God's boundless mercy for salvation.
